title: Qualitative immunoassay for the detection of anti-SARS-COV-2 spike antibody in human milk samples
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Day 1: prepare experimental plates
Timing: 30 min preparation, 12 h incubation
The experimental plates can be stored at −80°C for up to a week.
Coat plates with 50 μL of SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein at 0.5 ug/mL diluted in 1× PBS (pH 7.4).
Cover plates using plate sealers.
Day 2: ELISA experiment
Timing: 6 h
For this step, an indirect ELISA is performed - the proteins reactive to SARS-CoV-2 Spike in human milk would bind to SARS-CoV-2 Spike coating, then the HRP-conjugated secondary antibody (Anti-IgG/IgA/IgM/SC) is added to target the human proteins, TMB and HCl (1N) is added for a colorimetric reaction that can be read on the plate reader.
Retrieve and thaw human milk samples from freezer.
Fresh human milk samples can also be used in this protocol and all samples would be processed the same prior to storage as described in step 2 below.
When choosing negative control samples, we recommend including at least 10 pre-pandemic (pre-Dec 2019) milk samples to determine cutoff values. If these samples are not available, samples obtained after Dec 2019 from participants with no history of confirmed or suspected infection or known exposure to close contacts, though in this case more control samples (20–30) may be needed in order to remove significant outliers from the control dataset as these may be due to unknown previous SARS-CoV-2 infection.
Pre-pandemic control samples may be pooled to be used as a negative control in all experiments.
Similarly, positive samples can be pooled as a positive control to be used in each assay.
Screened controls should be included on every plate of each subsequent experiment to reduce plate-to-plate variation.
Centrifuge thawed samples in 50 mL conical tubes at 805×g for 10 min at 20°C–25°C.

Remove any remaining fat from the top of each sample.
Remove fat by scooping with a sterile spatula or by pouring off fat layer.
Samples can be frozen or used immediately.
Prepare 1× PBS/0.1% Tween-20 wash buffer.
We recommend preparing at least 4 liters wash buffer in a bottle that can be connected to the Tecan HydroSpeed plate washer, or similar to uniformly wash all wells of each plate.
Prepare blocking buffer using 0.1% PBS-T/3% goat serum/0.5% milk powder.
Wash plates using the Tecan HydroSpeed plate washer using prepared wash buffer.
Set up a program with 3 rounds of washing/aspiration filling to max capacity of your plate.
Note, plate washing can be performed manually while ensuring proper aspiration of all liquid before moving forward.
Add 50 μL blocking buffer to each well of your washed experimental plates.
Incubate experimental plates for 1 h at room temperature.
During the one hour incubation, set up 4-fold titrations in separate round-bottom polypropylene dilution plates with samples and any relevant controls (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]) at set concentrations in 1% BSA diluted in 1× PBS, pH 7.4.

Figure 1. Sample plate layout
Start titrations with undiluted processed milk to maximize sensitivity.
Include pre-pandemic/naïve and positive controls in the assay.
We recommend leaving a few wells without any samples and a few wells without any secondary antibody to ensure reagents are performing as expected.
After incubating for 1 h in blocking buffer, wash plates as described in step 6.
Transfer 50 μL of samples prepared in dilution plates to washed experimental plates.
Incubate covered experimental plates containing relevant samples for 2 h at room temperature.
Prepare goat anti-human secondary antibodies in 1× PBS, pH 7.4
We recommend using the following ratios of antibody to 1× PBS if using the ones specified above:
Goat anti-human IgA 1:6000

Goat anti-human IgG 1:2000
Goat anti-human IgM 1:2000
Goat anti-human secretory component (SC) 1:2000
After the experimental plates complete the 2 h incubation with samples, wash as described in step 6 using the Tecan HydroSpeed plate washer.
Add 50 μL prepared secondary antibodies to relevant experimental plates.
Note, one secondary is tested per set of samples. To test multiple secondary antibodies, set up relevant additional experimental plates.
Incubate covered experimental plates for 1 h at room temperature.
During this incubation, it is recommended to remove the TMB Substrate from 4°C to acclimate to room temperature.
After incubation with secondary antibodies, wash as described in step 6 using wash buffer.
Add 50 μL TMB Substrate to each well and allow plates to develop for 5–10 min, maintaining timing consistency with any future experiments.
If successful, you should see relevant saturation based on the dilutions set up to help determine the best amount of time needed to develop under your specific conditions for future experiments.
After the TMB Substrate has developed, add 25 μL 1N HCl to stop the reaction.
Promptly read endpoint data from experimental plates at an absorbance of 450 nm on BioTek Powerwave HT plate reader using BioTek Gen5 3.08 software, or similar.
Plate readers with the same specifications could be used at user’s discretion.
Export data as an Excel file for further analysis.
